qas.question: What is used to recover data if disks suffer a failure?
How can large quantities of data be accessed?
What do most database applications contain?
What is required for a modern DBMS to function?
What is used to destroy data if disks suffer a failure?
How can no quantities of data be accessed?
What do most database applications not integrate?
What is required for a broken DBMS to function?
What are non-dedicated computers that hold databases called?

context: Physically, <b8_0>database servers<b8_0/> are dedicated computers that hold the actual databases and run only the <b6_0>DBMS<b6_0/> and related software. Database servers are usually multiprocessor computers, with generous memory and <a0_0><b4_0>RAID<b4_0/><a0_0/> disk arrays used for stable storage. RAID is used for recovery of data if any of the disks fail. <a1_0><b5_0>Hardware database accelerators<b5_0/><a1_0/>, connected to one or more servers via a high-speed channel, are also used in large volume transaction processing environments. DBMSs are found at the heart of most database applications. <a2_0>DBMSs<a2_0/> may be built around a custom multitasking kernel with built-in networking support, but modern DBMSs typically rely on a <a3_0><b7_0>standard operating system<b7_0/><a3_0/> to provide these functions. from databases before the inception of Structured Query Language (SQL). The data recovered was disparate, redundant and disorderly, since there was no proper method to fetch it and arrange it in a concrete structure.[citation needed]
